title: FITT 3 Dance Handout Review Quiz - Set 1 (Questions 1-25)

questions.question: Dance is described as an expression of an intensified sense of life, arising from an inner perception that stimulates which two components?
The definition of Dance involves a successive group of bodily movements and steps rhythmically performed and timed to what?
The word "dance" is said to originate from which Latin word?
The Latin word "danson," from which "dance" is derived, means what?
Simple analysis suggests the Filipino word "sayaw" may have derived from the word "saya," which means what?
When dance is viewed as a form of recreation, it primarily provides which three benefits?
Which of the following is NOT listed as a purpose of dancing?
What is the primary focus when dance is considered an ART?
choices: To tell a story, set a mood, or express an emotion
questions.correctAnswer: To tell a story, set a mood, or express an emotion

questions.question: What is defined as a change of position in space, governed by mechanical principles that limit the ability of individuals to move effectively and efficiently?
What is defined as a measured motion or flow, characterized basically by recurrence of elements or features as beats, sounds or accents?
According to the simple equation provided in the handout, what is the result of combining Movement and Rhythm?
Which element of movement refers to the speed of the movement?
Which element of movement is characterized by components such as Direction, Level, Range, and Focus?
Which quality of Force/Energy is described as a sharp, driving movement, like an explosion?
A movement quality that is smooth, continuous, and does not have a clear beginning or end is known as what?
What type of movement involves moving the body from one place to another, such as walking, running, and jumping?
Which of the following is NOT an example of a Locomotor Movement?
What type of movement is performed around the axis of the body, such as bending, stretching, and turning?
What is the oldest form of dance, consisting of traditional dances of a country or region?
Primitive Dance was traditionally created for what primary purpose?
Which category of dance is created primarily to entertain or express an abstract idea, with examples like Ballet and Modern Dance?
Which type of dance is primarily used to tell a story or express an emotion or mood?
Which dance form is described as a rebellion against the traditions of classical ballet and often uses abstract ideas?
Natural Dance is characterized by its use of which three basic movement types?
Which dance is identified as the 'highest form of dance for the purpose of entertainment'?
What quality of Force/Energy is characterized by a sequence of tension and relaxation, often described as an arc or pendulum-like motion?
Which quality of Force/Energy is defined by giving into gravity, characterized by a sudden, complete relaxation of the body or a body part?
A movement quality that involves trembling or very short, sharp bursts of energy is known as what?
Which element of Movement Space refers to the vertical height of a movement, such as high, medium, or low?
Which element of Movement Space refers to the spatial orientation of the movement, such as moving forward, backward, or sideways?
The component of Space that refers to the width or size of the movement, from small, confined gestures to large, expansive steps, is called what?
In the element of Time/Rhythm, what refers to the underlying, steady rhythm of the music or movement?
What rhythmic element refers to the emphasis or force given to certain beats within a measure?
The speed or rate of movement, often expressed in terms of beats per minute, is referred to as what?
What Locomotor Movement involves a springing movement performed on one foot and landing on the same foot?
What Locomotor Movement is a combination of a step and a hop, alternating between the feet?
The simplest Locomotor Movement, defined as a series of steps executed by alternating the feet, is called a(n)...?
What Axial Movement involves a smooth, continuous movement of a body part to and fro, like a tree in the wind?
The Axial Movement that involves twisting a joint or body part around its own axis is called what?
What Axial Movement involves extending the limbs or trunk away from the center of the body?
Which of the following is listed as a physical benefit of dancing?
The purpose of dancing listed as 'For passion/provides/released of tension' falls primarily under which type of benefit?
The ability of the muscles to perform a continuous work without fatigue is known as what component of health-related fitness?
Which health-related fitness component relates to the percentage of fat, bone, and muscle mass in the human body?
The capacity of the heart and lungs to supply oxygen-rich blood to the working muscle tissues over an extended period is known as what?
The ability to exert a maximum effort in a single contraction, such as lifting a heavy weight, is known as what health-related component?
Which skill-related fitness component is the ability to change the direction of the body quickly and accurately?
The ability to use the senses together with body parts to perform movements accurately and smoothly is known as which skill-related component?
Which skill-related fitness component is the ability to control or stabilize the body, whether stationary or moving?
Recreational Dance includes which of the following specific types of dances?
choices: Dance Mixer, Square Dancing, and Round and Couple Dances
questions.correctAnswer: Dance Mixer, Square Dancing, and Round and Couple Dances

questions.question: In the FITT principle, what does the first 'T' stand for?
What is the recommended number of days per week for moderate-intensity physical activity according to the FITT guidelines?
What does the 'I' in the FITT principle stand for?
The measurement of how hard the body is working during physical activity is referred to as what FITT component?
The subjective method of measuring exercise intensity using a scale (often 1-10 or 6-20) is known as what?
What is the recommended duration for an aerobic dance session to meet the FITT guidelines for Time?
What does the second 'T' in the FITT principle stand for?
The 'Type' component of the FITT principle, when applied to a dance workout, relates to which fitness component?
What is the primary function of the **Warm-up** phase before the main dance workout?
choices: To prepare muscles and prevent injury
To lower the heart rate slowly
questions.correctAnswer: To prepare muscles and prevent injury

questions.question: The warm-up should include rhythmic movements that engage which part of the body to gently increase heart rate?
What type of stretching is recommended during the specific warm-up portion before the workout?
choices: Dynamic stretching related to the workout
questions.correctAnswer: Dynamic stretching related to the workout

questions.question: The main component of the physical activity program, which involves performing the dance routine or exercise, is called the...
What is the primary goal of the **Cool-down** phase of a dance workout?
choices: To maintain a high heart rate
To prevent blood pooling and decrease heart rate slowly
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent blood pooling and decrease heart rate slowly

questions.question: Which type of stretching, characterized by holding a stretch for a period of time, is appropriate for the cool-down phase?
How is Maximum Heart Rate (MHR) typically estimated for the purpose of calculating a safe Target Heart Rate?
What is the 'Talk Test' used to determine during a dance workout?
When dancing, if you are working at an intensity where you can talk comfortably but cannot sing, you are likely in which zone?
Which safety precaution recommends that you should always listen to your body and never force a position or movement?
Which dance type is set in a social gathering with a 'more formal atmosphere' than recreational dances?
What is the essential characteristic of **Natural Dance**?
choices: It is based on religious rituals
It is the natural movement of your body using basic, locomotor, and axial movement
It is performed by professional dancers only
questions.correctAnswer: It is the natural movement of your body using basic, locomotor, and axial movement

questions.question: Which dance type is highly recognized in television and dance centers like disco houses and social gatherings?
The purpose of dancing listed as 'To have fun or entertain others' falls under which primary benefit category?
Which Locomotor Movement is a springing movement where one foot pushes off and the body briefly suspends in the air before landing on the **opposite** foot?
The development of a sense of belonging and making new friends are listed as benefits under which dancing purpose?
choices: To have fun or entertain others
questions.correctAnswer: To have fun or entertain others

questions.question: What is the recommended method to ensure proper hydration during a dance workout?
choices: Drink water only after the cool-down
Drink water before, during, and after exercise
Consume large amounts of water immediately before the workout
questions.correctAnswer: Drink water before, during, and after exercise

questions.question: Which Locomotor Movement is described as a rapid movement where for a brief moment, both feet are off the ground?
The component of Space known as 'Focus' refers to where the dancer directs their...
What is the key difference between a **hop** and a **jump** in Locomotor Movements?
choices: Hop lands on both feet; Jump lands on one foot
Hop is done sideways; Jump is done forward
Hop lands on the same foot; Jump lands on two feet or the opposite foot
Hop is faster; Jump is slower
questions.correctAnswer: Hop lands on the same foot; Jump lands on two feet or the opposite foot

questions.question: The overall appearance and manner of carrying the body, which is a consideration for proper dance attire, is called...
Primitive Dance is most often associated with which context?
What is the specific component of skill-related fitness defined as the time taken to move once the need to move has been established?
Which health-related fitness component is primarily trained during the aerobic dance **Workout** phase?
The subjective intensity level where you can speak in short sentences, but feel 'somewhat hard' is described as...
Which component of the FITT principle dictates how often a person engages in physical activity?
What is the recommended number of days per week for stretching and flexibility exercises, according to general FITT guidelines for this component?
What is the recommended minimum duration for holding a static stretch during the cool-down phase?
What is the benefit of dancing described as 'to pass the course subject' categorized as?
The Axial Movement **shaking** is most closely related to which quality of Force/Energy?
The use of **dynamic stretching** during the warm-up is crucial for what purpose?
choices: Preparing muscles for intense movement and minimizing injury risk
questions.correctAnswer: Preparing muscles for intense movement and minimizing injury risk

questions.question: The ability to perform movements quickly is called **Speed**. What is the ability to transfer force quickly, often requiring a burst of energy, known as?
If a dancer moves their body in a large, sweeping motion, they are primarily manipulating which component of Space?
Which type of dance utilizes the highest degree of technical skills and often involves specific codified movements and vocabulary?
What happens in the body when blood pools in the extremities due to an abrupt stop after vigorous dancing?
Which of the following describes the **Gallop** Locomotor Movement?
choices: A step and cut, maintaining the same lead foot
questions.correctAnswer: A step and cut, maintaining the same lead foot

questions.question: In the FITT principle, **Intensity** can be objectively measured using which method?
A movement described as a sudden, brief halt or a momentary pause against gravity is known as what quality of Force/Energy?
When dancing, a change in body position from standing tall (high level) to crouching on the floor (low level) is primarily an adjustment of which element?
The primary role of the **Cool-down** phase is to transition the body from the workout back to a resting state, primarily by decreasing which physiological measure?
Which of the following is a key safety precaution for dance that helps prevent friction and blisters on the feet?
The combination of **Movement** and **Rhythm** results in Dance. In this equation, Movement is governed by what kind of principles?
